content.raw:
As far as I know, the submission process is still one image per vehicle so if you need different launch parameters per vehicle, you have to have multiple images \(not great but not the absolute worst with tagging\).

`/subt/start` is automatically called whenever you enter the environment from the staging area.  Likewise I _believe_ `/subt/finish` is automatically called whenever your allotted time runs out.
content.html:
As far as I know, the submission process is still one image per vehicle so if you need different launch parameters per vehicle, you have to have multiple images (not great but not the absolute worst with tagging).

/subt/start is automatically called whenever you enter the environment from the staging area. Likewise I believe /subt/finish is automatically called whenever your allotted time runs out.

content.raw: We’d also like confirmation on the current penalties structure for sending multiples of the same artifact to the base station - documentation is inconsistent \(see the API page in the wiki\): Can we submit the same artifact as many times as we wish without penalty, or are we still limited to 2 times? Since acknowledgements can be dropped, the former makes more sense.
content.html: We’d also like confirmation on the current penalties structure for sending multiples of the same artifact to the base station - documentation is inconsistent (see the API page in the wiki): Can we submit the same artifact as many times as we wish without penalty, or are we still limited to 2 times? Since acknowledgements can be dropped, the former makes more sense.

content.raw: It is stated that you can submit the same artifact as many times as you like without penalty as it counts as one submission as long as the submitted location is exactly the same.  I am not exactly aware of the maximum number of times you can submit unique artifact locations so I’ll start investigating.  I am aware there is a limit as I have encountered it during testing.
content.html: It is stated that you can submit the same artifact as many times as you like without penalty as it counts as one submission as long as the submitted location is exactly the same. I am not exactly aware of the maximum number of times you can submit unique artifact locations so I’ll start investigating. I am aware there is a limit as I have encountered it during testing.

content.raw:
According to Section 11.3 of the [SubT Challenge Tunnel Circuit Rules Document](https://www.subtchallenge.com/resources/SubT_Challenge_Tunnel_Rules.pdf):

_For the Tunnel Circuit, the total number of artifacts is 20 and the total number of allowed scored reports is 40. Once an artifact has been successfully reported, any duplicate reports will be considered invalid and will count against the total number of reports._

But according to the [API Documentation](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/api):

_Repeated artifact requests \(a request is considered repeated when contains the same artifact type and position as a previously sent request\) do not count as new requests for scoring purposes. In other words, a team will not lose an extra token while retrying to send a previously reported artifact._

‌

@{5be108d7216ccf49622e6b67} , thank you for pointing this out. We will work to resolve shortly.
content.html:
According to Section 11.3 of the SubT Challenge Tunnel Circuit Rules Document:

For the Tunnel Circuit, the total number of artifacts is 20 and the total number of allowed scored reports is 40. Once an artifact has been successfully reported, any duplicate reports will be considered invalid and will count against the total number of reports.

But according to the API Documentation:

Repeated artifact requests (a request is considered repeated when contains the same artifact type and position as a previously sent request) do not count as new requests for scoring purposes. In other words, a team will not lose an extra token while retrying to send a previously reported artifact.

‌

@Sarah Kitchen , thank you for pointing this out. We will work to resolve shortly.

content.raw:
@{5be108d7216ccf49622e6b67}, The [cloudsim documentation on the wiki](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/qual_cloudsim) is up to date. A docker image is required, not a docker-compose.yml file. The docker-compose.yml file is used locally to mimic the [cloudsim architecture](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/cloudsim_architecture). I added a couple lines about the alpha-numeric requirement for robot names.

If you need to pass arguments into your solution image, then you will have to build a separate image for each robot and incorporate the parameters into the image. This is something we'd like to change, but it's a non-trivial enhancement.

In terms of a checklist, there is nothing mandatory that you must do. You can call `/subt/start` and `/subt/finish` if you want to, but these are both optional.

Cloudsim uses the same docker versions as found on [dockerhub](https://cloud.docker.com/u/osrf/repository/docker/osrf/subt-virtual-testbed).

Checkout the [system requirements](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/system_requirements) page for information about nvidia version.
content.html:
@Sarah Kitchen, The cloudsim documentation on the wiki is up to date. A docker image is required, not a docker-compose.yml file. The docker-compose.yml file is used locally to mimic the cloudsim architecture. I added a couple lines about the alpha-numeric requirement for robot names.

If you need to pass arguments into your solution image, then you will have to build a separate image for each robot and incorporate the parameters into the image. This is something we'd like to change, but it's a non-trivial enhancement.

In terms of a checklist, there is nothing mandatory that you must do. You can call /subt/start and /subt/finish if you want to, but these are both optional.

Cloudsim uses the same docker versions as found on dockerhub.

Checkout the system requirements page for information about nvidia version.
